ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about fi, film techniques, and the cultural relevance of many films specifically  relating to Europe/Eastern Europe
Detailed study of documentary and docufiction works
I received a clearer understanding of the literature addressing theories of fictionality and historical narratives.

An in-depth knowledge of narratological frameworks for distinguishing between fictionality and factuality, as well as insights into the applicability of these categories to Eastern European cinematic movements.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Overall a great course. Maybe some more grading structure/insight during the year. Professor MacKay really brought a lot of energy and passion to the classroom.

I believe that the course provided an ambitious screening schedule that introduced me to a variety of films I had never otherwise had the opportunity to see. However, at times the screenings felt more laborious considering the length of time spent in the theater. Considering that we watched so many films, we rarely had the opportunity to discuss all of them in class. Many remain enigmatic to my understanding because I was not able to address questions in class and get ideas from my fellow classmates.

This class was extremely disorganized and not conducive to fostering an engaged classroom atmosphere. There seemed to be almost no concrete plan at the beginning of each day, and discussions would get derailed by extensive tangents from both students and the professor. The professor also cancelled the Friday class that was supposed to be the first meeting of the class (it was a Monday class, so due to scheduling, it was placed on a Friday since the following Monday of add/drop was a holiday). This seemed as though it was a tactic to trap students in the class given that we had never gotten the opportunity to shop it during the add/drop period since we didn't have class until after add/drop.
I really enjoyed the mixture of theoretical works and cinematic and written texts in the course. I think the movement between different media was important to ground the idea of "docu-fiction."

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes I would. If you are interested in older films. Professor MacKay is fantastic.
I would definitely recommend this course to any student. This course was not only fascinating, but also provided a vital space for thinking through aesthetic and ethical questions.

Yes, I would recommend this course to those interested in understanding the nature of cinematic narrative, as well as how this narratological framework undergirds the constitution of fictional and documentarian trends in art. I would also recommend this course to those interested in the historical nature of filmic experimentation.
